thread.title: Rams projected to get three compensatory selections in 2017 NFL Draft
thread.title_full: Rams projected to get three compensatory selections in 2017 NFL Draft

title: Rams projected to get three compensatory selections in 2017 NFL Draft
text:
Rams projected to get three compensatory selections in 2017 NFL Draft Rams projected to get three compensatory selections in 2017 NFL Draft By Bryan Kalbrosky 9 hours ago 257 shares By: Bryan Kalbrosky | 9 hours ago 
The Los Angeles Rams lost Janoris Jenkins, Rodney McLeod and Nick Fairley to free agency last year. But they may get draft picks in return. 
In addition to a first-round pick as well as two second-round picks and a third-round pick last year, the Rams traded their first and third-round picks in the upcoming draft for No. 1 overall pick Jared Goff as well. Related: Picturing a Rams draft without the Jared Goff trade, future and past 
Here’s how one writer explained the situation for Los Angeles ( via Turf Show Times ): 
“If the Rams receive a third-round compensatory pick, the compensatory pick goes to the Titans and the Rams keep their natural third-round selection. Otherwise, the Titans would get the Rams’ natural third-rounder.” 
According to Over The Cap , this is the first year that compensatory draft picks are allowed to be traded. 
The report projects the Rams will receive a third round pick for Jenkins. McLeod is expected to yield a fourth round selection while Fairley will likely bring a sixth rounder. 
Here’s how compensatory draft picks are awarded in the NFL ( via AdamTJ13 ): 
“As the NFL explains, compensatory picks are awarded to teams that lose more or better compensatory free agents than they acquire. The number of picks a team can receive equals the net loss of compensatory free agents, up to a maximum of four.” 
If the OTC projections are correct, the Rams will have four choices in the first 150 selections of the upcoming NFL Draft. 
While that’s not fantastic, there are certainly plenty of talented players the team can draft to fill some of their needs. Related:
